Dear Ms. Thorpe:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan failed to
achieve compliance.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
There is an issue with the heat at this facility that has been present for a couple of
weeks. The youth have to wear coats indoors due to temperatures of 54 degrees.
The owner is believed to be unwilling to pay for needed repairs.
INVESTIGATION:
This anonymous complaint was forwarded on 02/08/21 and was assigned for joint
investigation with the DHHS Specialist. The initial allegations were as follows:
There are believed to be around 5 to 6 young women living at Let's Talk About It
Girls Home. There is concern for all of the residents. It is very cold in the building
because there is an unknown problem with the heat. This has been ongoing for
at least a couple of weeks. The young women are having to wear coats in the
/building due to the low temperatures of around 54 degrees. The owner is
believed to be unwilling to pay for needed repairs. A few small space heaters
were purchased, however it is still very cold in the building.
I conducted an unannounced onsite inspection of the facility on 02/08/21 after
receiving this complaint. This onsite inspection and interviews were completed jointly
with the DHHS Specialist. The Administrative Assistant was present and assisted
with a tour of the facility. The facility is a large three-story older home. Upon entering
the home, the temperature was observed to be cold. The main areas of the home on
the main level, including the kitchen, dining room, and living room were found to be
cold. Some spots were warmer than others but overall, it felt cold on the main floor.
The thermometer for this level was located in the living room and was observed to
be 60 degrees when first observed and moved up to 61 degrees when the heat
came on. There was plastic covering most of the main floor windows and the
Administrative Assistant reported that to be relatively new. An electric portable space
heating fireplace was in the living room and was on. The Administrative Assistant
said that this was brought in over the previous weekend by the Chief Administrator.
There was a separate room with desks and another room that was being made into
a sensory room on the main floor. Those rooms felt warmer than the open main
areas. The Administrative Assistant reported that the Chief Administrator had been
in contact with a heating company who had done some maintenance and repairs to
the furnace and the ducts running through the home. The Administrative Assistant
reported that the building had become colder with the recent colder weather and
some of the youth and staff had mentioned it. It was noted that the Administrative
Assistant works Monday through Friday and staff over the weekend reported that it
was extremely cold in the building. The second floor was toured as well and was
observed to feel significantly warmer. The bedrooms are located on the second floor
and we went into each room. Some were warmer than others but there were none
that seemed cold. The thermostat on the second floor read 74 degrees. There was a
third floor to the home, but the youth do not go on that floor.
4

Youths A, B, C and D were all individually interviewed jointly with the DHHS
Specialist in the sensory room on the main floor. All youth reported that it has been
cold in the building for several weeks and has recently gotten even colder. Some of
the youth reported wearing their coats inside, wearing layers, and needing blankets
to keep warm. The youth said that the school room and the sensory rooms were
warmer when they kept the doors closed, but not all staff will let them keep the doors
closed. The youth said that staff did not make them shower in the main floor
bathroom over the weekend due to it being so cold in the building. The youth
reported that upstairs is warmer, and their bedrooms are warmer. The youth
reported that the portable fireplace was brought in over the previous weekend to
help with the heat. The youth further reported that staff have been boiling pots of
water on the stove and have had the oven on with the oven door open to help heat
the main floor.
The Chief Administrator (CA), the Chief Administrator in training, Quality Supervisor
and the Director of Youth Services came to the building during the youth interviews.
After meeting with the youth, the DHHS Specialist and I interviewed these
administrative staff jointly. The CA reported that they noticed it was “chilly” in the two
main rooms on the main floor, so they covered the windows with plastic. Per the CA,
this was the first winter in the building and they did not know that there was a
heating issue. Reportedly, the building had been previously licensed but closed and
sat empty for some time prior to the facility opening this program last spring. (I
confirmed in BITS that the program was licensed 03/18/20.) The CA stated that she
had a company making repairs to cracks in the ducts/vents and another looking at
maintenance on the furnace. The CA confirmed that she brought in the portable
fireplace and was advised that this was not permitted under licensing rules. The CA
agreed that it was cool in the building but reported that the thermostat was giving a
false low reading due to the wall it is mounted on being cold. The CA was advised
that, if that were the issue then she needed to remedy the installation of the
thermostat as that was what I needed to use, per the rule, to verify the temperature
in the building. The CA further reported that they had moved a television into the
sensory room so that the youth could watch television in the warmer room, rather
than in the front living room where it was notably colder. The CA was also advised
that staff are to immediately be advised that they are not to boil pots of water nor use
the open oven to heat the building. The CA indicated that she would direct them to
stop immediately.
I interviewed Staff 1 on 02/08/21, at the facility, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Staff 1 reported that it has been cold in the building and she is not sure what the
issues are, but noted the CA was working to figure it out. Staff 1 said that she had
just returned from being out of work for a couple of weeks and said that it was not
this cold inside before she left.
I interviewed Staff 2 on 02/08/21, at the facility, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Staff 2 reported that it has been cold in the building since it got colder (10-12
degrees) outside. Staff 2 said that it was just the kitchen and living room that were
5

cold and that the sensory room and school room were warm, as were the bedrooms
and upstairs. Staff 2 said that she put up the plastic on the windows to help with the
heat.
I emailed all related DHHS Foster Care Workers for Youths A, B, C, and D. None of
the workers noted complaints by the youth related to the temperature of the building.
All of the workers reported that the building was not cold during their monthly visits.
One Foster Care Worker did report it was “cool but not uncomfortable” but went on
to report that she likes the temperature set at 75 degrees. None had concerns
related to safety or the heat.
Additional email and telephone contacts were made with the CA over the next few
days. The CA provided updates to her progress with the furnace company making
repairs and assessing for a new furnace. On 02/11/21, the CA called to advised she
was moving all of the residents to a Residence Inn due to the heating company
installing a new furnace. This resolution fit with the facility’s emergency policy. The
youth would still be staffed and would all have their own bed. There is a kitchenette
and dining table and chairs in the room.
The CA emailed on 02/13/21 and reported that the new furnace was installed, and
the temperature had reached 69 degrees. A picture of the thermostat was provided
for verification.
On 02/16/21, Consultant 2 made an unannounced onsite visit to the facility and
advised that the temperature was observed to be 61 degrees on the main floor.
Consultant 2 said that the dining area and front living room were still cold, but the
kitchen area was warmer. Consultant 2 said that he spoke with the youth and they
reported that it was warmer in the building and they were more comfortable.
Consultant 2 reported that the portable fireplace was disabled but still in the living
room.
On 02/18/21, the CA emailed the following,
We are continuing to assess the heat issue. On Tuesday 2/16/2 I caulked the
windows in the front room and recovered them with plastic to keep air out and the
temperature rose up to 65 degrees and held steady there overnight. On
Wednesday morning 2/17/21 the furnace company came back out to balance the
heats distribution through the registers. They pushed more heat towards the front
room. The heat is teetering back and forth between 68 degrees and 72 degrees.
The CA attached three pictures of the thermostat that read 68, 69, and 72 degrees.
Another email and accompanying picture of the thermostat was received at 8:00pm
on 02/18/21 and noted the temperature to be holding at 75 degrees. Another email
with a short video of the thermostat and surrounding area, was received from the CA
on 02/19/21, and documented the heat at 73 degrees which is above the required 68
degrees.
6

On 02/24/21, Consultant 2 made an onsite visit to the facility and advised that the
temperature was 76 degrees on the main floor.
Documents reviewed as part of this investigation include the following:
 Utility Failure Emergency, revised 01/10/21
 02/12/21 email from the Chief Administrator to the furnace company related to
a 02/08/21 onsite by the company and their plans to continue working on the
heating issue. In a follow up email, the CA said that the 60,000 BTU furnace
will be replaced by a larger furnace with 100,000 BTUs.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4431 Heating equipment.
(1) Heating equipment shall be capable of maintaining a
temperature of not less than 68 degrees Fahrenheit at a
point 4 feet above the floor. An accurate thermometer shall
be provided.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as the temperature was
observed to be at 61 degrees on the main floor. The Chief
Administrator acknowledged that this was due largely to the
inadequate furnace, which was replaced. A CAP is still required.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The facility was found to be using an electric heating device that is not permitted
under the rules. During an unannounced inspection to the facility on 02/08/21, I
observed that an electric space heater was being used in the living room to assist
with improving the heat in the house. The Chief Administrator was advised that this
type of heating device is not permitted under the licensing rules. The Chief
Administrator later reported that she confirmed this with the Qualified Fire Inspector
who also said they could not use the heater.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4552 Heating devices and flame producing devices.
(4) Portable heaters and space heaters, including solid fuel
heaters, are prohibited.
7

ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as they were using a
portable, electric fireplace space heater in the living room to
assist with heating the area. The fireplace was disabled;
however, a CAP is still required.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable and timely corrective action plan.
